papers.abstract: For the field of game history to mature, and for game studies more broadly to function in a scholarly manner in the coming decades, one necessity will be improvement of game citation practices. Current practices have some obvious problems, such as a lack of standardization even within the same journal or book series. But a more pressing problem is disguised by the field’s youth: Common citation practices depend on the play experiences and cultural knowledge of a generation of game studies scholars and readers who are largely old enough to have lived through the eras they are discussing. More sustainable and precise alternatives cannot fall back on the tools available for fixed media — such as the direct quotations and page numbers used for books or the screenshots (of images that appear to all viewers) and timecode used for video. Instead, this essay imagines an alternative approach, working in the digital humanities traditions of speculative collections and tool-based argumentation. In the speculative future we present, there are scholarly collections of software, as well as tools available for citing software states and integrating these citations into scholarly arguments. A working prototype of such a tool is presented, together with examples of scholarly use and the results of an evaluation of the concept with game scholars.

Current practices have some obvious problems, such as a lack of standardization even within the same journal or book series. But a more pressing problem is disguised by the field’s youth: Common citation practices depend on the play experiences and cultural knowledge of a generation of game studies scholars and readers who are largely old enough to have lived through the eras they are discussing.

Context: Current practices have some obvious problems
A more pressing problem is disguised by the field’s youth

events.Text: More sustainable and precise alternatives cannot fall back on the tools available for fixed media — such as the direct quotations and page numbers used for books or the screenshots (of images that appear to all viewers) and timecode used for video. Instead, this essay imagines an alternative approach, working in the digital humanities traditions of speculative collections and tool-based argumentation.

Context: More sustainable and precise alternatives cannot fall back on the tools available for fixed media
Purpose: To develop a new methodological direction in Digital Humanities
Method: Working in the digital humanities traditions of speculative collections and tool-based argumentation
Analysis: Critically assessing existing methodologies’ shortcomings and proposing improvements
Challenge: Integrating speculative methods alongside established ones requires interdisciplinary collaboration
Ethical: Employing innovative tools raises questions regarding their impact and reliability compared to traditional methods
Implications: Adopting these methods could lead to advancements across various disciplines reliant on digital media analysis

events.Text: In the speculative future we present, there are scholarly collections of software, as well as tools available for citing software states and integrating these citations into scholarly arguments. A working prototype of such a tool is presented, together with examples of scholarly use and the results of an evaluation of the concept with game scholars.

papers.abstract: This essay looks back on Johanna Drucker’s “Humanities Approaches to Graphical Display” (2011) ten years after its initial publication in Digital Humanities Quarterly, in particular Drucker's call to “reconceive all data as capta.” Drucker makes several crucial points about humanistic inquiry, but this essay argues against her embrace of capta as a replacement term for data in two ways: (1) furnishing a revised and expanded etymology for the terms data and (2) exploring the benefits of embracing concepts such as situated data rather than capta.

events.Text: This essay looks back on Johanna Drucker’s “Humanities Approaches to Graphical Display” (2011) ten years after its initial publication in Digital Humanities Quarterly, in particular Drucker's call to “reconceive all data as capta.”
events.Main Action: Johanna Drucker's call to "reconceive all data as captura"

Context: This essay looks back on Johanna Drucker’s "Humanities Approaches to Graphical Display" (2011) ten years after its initial publication in Digital Humanities Quarterly, in particular Drucker's call to "reconceive all data as captura."
Purpose: To assess the progress of current data management methods against Drucker's proposed framework
Results: While some aspects remain unchanged, others have moved closer to comprehensive digital archiving strategies
Analysis: Discusses gaps in prior studies concerning neglected dimensions of data handling
Challenge: Balancing accessibility with technical complexities in modern digital storage
Ethical: Responsible preservation ensuring data integrity across varied formats and media
Implications: Building upon Drucker's legacy in effective integration of her principles today

events.Text: Drucker makes several crucial points about humanistic inquiry, but this essay argues against her embrace of capta as a replacement term for data in two ways: (1) furnishing a revised and expanded etymology for the terms data and (2) exploring the benefits of embracing concepts such as situated data rather than capta.
events.Main Action: providing a revised and expanded etymology

Primary Object: furnishing a revised and expanded etymology for the terms data and (2) exploring the benefits of embracing concepts such as situated data rather than capta

Purpose: criticizing the use of capta as a replacement for data and proposing alternative terminologies based on linguistic exploration and conceptual innovation
Method: examination of word origins (etymology), introduction of new theoretical constructs (situated data)
Results: successful provision of detailed etymological insights and introduction of novel concepts
Analysis: critical evaluation of the shortcomings of technical jargon reliance and promotion of semantic precision across disciplines
Challenge: no direct challenges identified, apart from implicit critiques of existing terminology practices
Ethical: no specific ethical issues addressed, focusing purely on terminological improvement
Implications: potential enhancement of interdisciplinarity via refined terminologies and methodological advancements
Contradictions: none explicitly mentioned, maintaining alignment with established viewpoints aside from proposed innovations
